article_title: Last-minute way to reduce 2014 taxes? Contribute to an IRA
article_text:
Last-minute way to reduce 2014 taxes? Contribute to an IRA

If you purchased subsidized health insurance through Covered California, you might be able to reduce your tax bill by making a deductible contribution to a regular IRA by April 15.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Kathleen Pender
article_metadata.description: If you purchased subsidized health insurance through Covered California, you might be able to reduce your tax bill by making a deductible contribution to a regular IRA by April 15.  [...] if you can, it will reduce your 2014 modified adjusted gross income, which generally will increase your premium tax credit and result in a bigger refund (or lower tax due) when you file your 2014 returns.  The IRA contribution will also reduce your regular income tax, if you earned enough to have an income tax liability for 2014.  [...] contributing to a Roth will not lower your income or increase your health care subsidy.  Under the act, most people who don’t have health coverage through work or a government program such as Medicare can get a subsidy to purchase health insurance through a marketplace if their modified adjusted gross income falls between 138 and 400 percent of the federal poverty limit for their household size.  The credit for health coverage in 2014 depends on your 2014 income.  [...] when people signed up for coverage starting in 2014, they qualified for a tax credit based on their estimated 2014 income.  Many people chose to have the tax credit applied directly to their premium, resulting in a smaller out-of-pocket cost each month.  The premium tax credit is independent from your regular tax liability, said Jay Wiedwald, a volunteer tax preparer with Tax-Aide.  Even if you don’t owe regular income tax, if you earned more than anticipated, you could have to repay some of your premium tax credit.  Some people, instead of taking their subsidy throughout the year, chose to pay all their health insurance premium out of pocket.  No matter how they received the subsidy, almost anyone who got it could benefit from making a tax-deductible contribution to a regular IRA because it will reduce their income and increase their credit.
